results.title: Film continuity
results.creator_credit: Peter Thompson, Eric Halliday and AFTRS
results.brief_description: This film conveys the importance of technical, pictorial and narrative continuity and pre-planning for these. It also notes continuity of screen direction such as awareness of movement in the frame, eye lines and reverse shots. The function of the “continuity girl” or script supervisor is explained. Script by Caroline Stanton. This film is suitable for upper secondary students.

results.title: Editing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Covers cutting on action and in terms of graphics; and by following the shooting of a sequence through to the editing of the final product indicates how editing can serve to expand, compress and rearrange time.

results.title: Image and screen
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Notes how advances in technology have created greater realism on the screen. Shows how the definition or clarity of detail of the photographed image can be altered by filters, vaseline and netting. Also explains depth of field and exposure. Narrated by Peter Thomson. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: In continuo
results.creator_credit: Vlatko Gilic, Dunav Film and Phoenix Films
results.brief_description: Non-narrated treatment of the activities carried out in an abattoir. An unlikely subject for a documentary, but the filmmaker captures the strength and terrible beauty in the daily preparation for slaughter. The sound track echoes with hard metallic knives being ground, tested and sharpened. No beast is actually shown being killed but the slaughter is mirrored in the blood-red faces of the men and the scenes of water flushing away the blood to a river - thus water purges but never really cleans the walls of the slaughter house. A powerful film - almost abstract at times. Perhaps even more effective because of what it leaves unsaid and unshown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vlatko Gilic, Dunav Film and Phoenix Films

results.title: Communication: getting in touch
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow and Bosustow Entertainment
results.brief_description: An alien colony settles on earth and language differences present a problem. This film shows in a humorous way how communicating with others involves getting in touch with their ways of exchanging information; and how to overcome the three barriers to communication: linguistic, sociological and personal. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: William Faulkner's barn burning
results.creator_credit: Peter Werner, Calvin Skaggs and Learning in Focus
results.brief_description: Based on a William Faulkner story set in the late nineteenth century in which a young boy faces the agonizing decision of whether or not to betray his embittered father, who burns his employer’s barn in an act of revenge. Series hosted by Henry Fonda and stars Tommy Lee Jones.

results.title: Mark Twain's 'The man that corrupted Hadleyburg'
results.creator_credit: Ralph Rosenblum, Christopher Lucas and Perspective Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The American Short Story”.
Based on the story of the same title by Mark Twain, about a small town visited by a stranger who concocts a scheme to test the honesty of the town’s leading citizens. Stars Robert Preston, hosted by Henry Fonda.

results.title: The Sky is gray
results.creator_credit: Stan Lathan, Whitney Green and Perspective Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The American Short Story”.
Based on a short story by Ernest Gaines. Deals with a young black farmboy’s visit to the dentist in a small Louisiana town in the 1940’s. The visit marks the dawning of his social and self-awareness. Commentary by Henry Fonda. Cast: Olivia Cole, James Bond III.
